description: From Middle English, from stem incumbent-, of Medieval Latin incumbēns (“holder of a church position”), from Latin present participle of incumbō (“I lie down upon”).

adjectives.description: incumbent (comparative more incumbent, superlative most incumbent)

entries.meaning: (Used with "on" or "upon") Imposed on someone as an obligation, especially due to one's office.
examples: Proper behavior is incumbent on all holders of positions of trust.
to move the incumbent load they try

entries.meaning: (botany, geology) Resting on something else; in botany, said of anthers when lying on the inner side of the filament, or of cotyledons when the radicle lies against the back of one of them
(zoology) Bent downwards so that the ends touch, or rest on, something else.
examples: the incumbent toe of a bird

entries.meaning: Being the current holder of an office or a title.
examples: If the incumbent senator dies, he is replaced by a person appointed by the governor.

entries.meaning: The current holder of an office, such as ecclesiastical benefice or an elected office.
examples: Mr Obama’s problems were partly structural. An incumbent must defend the realities and compromises of government, while a challenger is freer to promise the earth, details to follow. Mr Obama’s odd solution was to play both incumbent and challenger, jumping from a defence of his record to indignation at such ills as over-crowded classrooms and tax breaks for big oil companies.

entries.meaning: (business) A holder of a position as supplier to a market or market segment that allows the holder to earn above-normal profits.
examples: American capitalism is becoming like its European cousin: established firms with the scale and scope to deal with a growing thicket of regulations are doing well, but new companies are withering on the vine or selling themselves to incumbents.
